fields.physical_description:
[Instructions booklet for card game] Design: letterpress
No. of cards: 57
fields.title: A New & Compendious System of Geography on Cards

fields.name:
Type: whist, pope, loo
Subject: geography

fields.history_note: [Instructions booklet for card game] This can be played a number of ways using the basis of Whist, including the games of Pope and Loo.
fields.historical_context_note:
[Instructions booklet for card game] Rewards: whist counters if wanted
Forfeits: if played by whist rules
No. of Players: any
Equipment required: pack of 56 cards printed with geographical information, with one card describing the geographical terms employed
8 page descriptive booklet of rules 

Rules:
An Explanation of a New and Compendious System of Geography on Cards Which Admit of Various Instructive and Entertaining Games.
An Explanation of the Geographical Cards
It is justly remarked, that the knowledge of Geography, though a favourite Branch of modern Education, is for the most part indistinctly acquired, and imperfectly retained.--A principal cause seems to be the Want of a Syllabus, comprising in a clear and compendious form the chief Heads of this Science, and such as deserve a place in the Memory.  A Method of this kind seems absolutely necessary for the Instruction of children, to whose taste and capacity the Subject is peculiarly adapted, most systems of Geography being too late and diffuse, or altogether trifling and inaccurate.
This Epitome of Geography was originally drawn up for the use of a private school, and principally designed for children, but may not be beneath the attention of any who wish to acquire a general knowledge of this science.  The preliminary cards, viz. the six first numbers, No. 30, 31,39 and 46 contain the general Division of the Earth and Sea, the four Quarters of the World, their principal lands, their chief Seas and the Course of the most celebrated rivers, No. 52 contains the West India Islands, and No 56, Countries little known.  The other cards contain the Geography of particular countries in Miniature viz. their boundaries, divisions, chief towns, religion, government, universities, produce and manufactures, mountains, rivers and lakes.
It may be proper to observe, that in reciting the divisions of the several Quarters of the world and the provinces of each particular kingdom, I have generally begun with the N. and taken the countries from W to E in different lines, in a manner analogous to that of reading from the left hand to the right.  In mentioning the Islands of each Quarter of the World, I have begun NW and taken them in order by way of the S to NE unless some obvious reason interfered.  This will be a great help to the knowledge of the maps, with which the cards should be diligently compared.  Thus, for instance, in No. 2 Sweden succeeds Norway, Russia, Sweden and Turkey which is mentioned last, is the most south easterly country in Europe.  So also in the Asiatic Isles, I begin with Cyprus in the Levant, proceed to Bombay and Goa and terminate with the Isles of Kamschatka.
In the article of chief towns, the first in order is the Metropolis and those marked in Italics are Sea Ports and Harbours.
The Manufactures are separated from the Produce by a short Line.
The Contractions are few and scarcely need an explanation.  Besides those of Boun. Div. etc. which are contained at length in No. 7, N stands for North, S South, E East, W West and in No. 52 the chief towns are mentions in italics, and the following contractions made use of E. English, Sp Spanish, Fr. French, Dan Danish, Du Dutch.
As every circumstance is of importance that engages the attention of young minds, and renders Science more easy and agreeable, this system is printed on cards, which admit of various instructive and amusing games.  I shall mention the two which first occurred, and they may be diversified, or others contrived at pleasure.  The somewhat resembles the game called POPE in which cards are played in succession, No.10 after No 9, No. 11 after 10, etc. and he who has first played off this cards is the winner.  Let then the preliminary, or general cards, as before specified  be taken from the back and the rest dealt to the company who chuse to play.  The backs only are allowed to be seen, which contain their numbers and titles.  The eldest hand nominates some particular Topic, as Religion, Rivers etc which every one recites as he plays, or keeps his card and the lead passes to the next in order.  If there be a stop occasioned by the succeeding card having been laid aside, or already played, he who played the last has a right to begin again.--Thus, suppose I am the eldest hand, and have four cards, No. 9,11,27 and 29.  The article I nominate is Religion, and I play off No. 27, Spain, Religion Popish.  Some one else plays No. 28, Italy and its Islands, Religion Popish.  I then play No. 29, Turkey in Europe, Religion Mahometan and Greek Church, which being a stop, I begin another lead, No. 9, Ireland, Religion etc.  Some one else plays No. 10 and I conclude with No. 11.  It will be still more like the Game of POPE, if some reward be annexed to the playing of particular cards, as for instance, all the Stops.
The other game resembles LOO or Whist (if played by four) where the superior number triumphs, the leader nominating the article and the rest being obliged to repeat it with the cards they play or forfeit a trick.
If this system should appear too long, it may be accommodated to different ages and capacities by omitting or abridging some of the article, mentioning the number instead of the names of the Provinces, the Metropolis, instead of chief towns, or the distinguishing produce and manufacture of a country:  or the Geography of Europe may be first learned and that of the other parts of the world postponed.  Experience, however, shews that children are soon capable of making considerable progress in this Science, which is principally an object of Sense and Memory.  Any every judicious person will consider it as a matter of serious importance, to give them an early acquaintance with words and things, and especially to initiate them in those studies that tend to gratify their natural curiosity to open and enlarge the mind, to promote a spirit of enquiry and inspire the love of knowledge.
